resources.string: Get Tips For Your Green Friend

Disease Name: Botrytis (or gray mold). Symptoms: Gray mold appears on the leaves, stem, flowers, and fruit. Environment: This fungus grows in mild and humid environments, in poorly ventilated spaces. Treatment: To prevent this fungus from appearing during cultivation, make sure to properly space the plants when planting. Cut off the parts that have been infected, then spray Bordeaux mixture over all parts of the plant.

Disease Name: Circoporiosis. Symptoms: Gray spots appear on the leaves. Environment: This fungus appears during cold weather in wet environments. Treatment: Treat diseased leaves with Bordeaux mixture or sulfur. To prevent the disease, make sure to properly space the plants when planting.

Disease Name: Fusariosis. Symptoms: The plant wilts. The root rots. The leaves turn yellow. Environment: This fungus develops in heavy, wet, and poorly aerated soil. Treatment: Sprinkle the plant with an organic, sulfur or copper-based fungicide.

Disease Name: Downy mildew. Symptoms: Brown spots appear on the leaves. The leaves then begin to fall to the ground. Environment: This fungus develops in very hot weather and significant humidity. Treatment: When spots appear on the leaves, cut the infected leaves off so they do not contaminate other plants. Then spray Bordeaux mixture on the leaves. Apply nettle slurry to the leaves after watering.

Disease Name: Powdery mildew. Symptoms: A white layer appears on the leaves (a mold is forming). Environment: This fungus develops in hot, very humid environments. Treatment: Properly space the plants at the time of planting. Cut off any infected leaves. Then spray the leaves with a mixture of milk and water (around 17 ounces of milk and one gallon of water) each week.

Disease Name: Phytophtora cinnamoni. Symptoms: The leaves and stem wilt, turn yellow, and dry out.The root rots. Environment: This fungus develops in hot and wet environments. Treatment: Cut and burn infected leaves to avoid contamination of surrounding plants, then spray Bordeaux mixture on the leaves.

Disease Name: Ramularia. Symptoms: Light brown spots appear. Leaves then dry out. Environment: The fungus appears in hot, very humid environments, in poorly aerated spaces. Treatment: To do as much as possible to prevent this disease from appearing, space plants well in rows at the time of planting. Cut off the leaves that have been infected, then spray Bordeaux mixture over the leaves.

Disease Name: Blight. Symptoms: Red spots form on the leaves, causing the leaves to fall. Environment: This fungus develops when the weather is wet or when plants are too frequently watered. The fungus can appear starting in the beginning of spring through the end of summer. Treatment: When the first signs of the disease appear, cut and then burn infected leaves to avoid contaminating other plants. Then spray the leaves with a sulfur solution, horsetail slurry, or nettle slurry.

Disease Name: Flea beetles. Symptoms: Holes appear in the leaves (especially young leaves). Environment: Flea beetles appear in hot and dry weather. Treatment: Spray nettle slurry on the leaves. Watering daily prevents this insect from appearing, as it does not like water.

Disease Name: Spider mites. Symptoms: They suck the sap from plants. The leaves turn yellow. Small, whitish webs appear on the leaves. The plant withers. Environment: This pest thrives in hot and dry weather. Treatment: Spray water on the leaves, because spider mites do not like wet environments.

Disease Name: Pests: Caterpillars. Symptoms: Caterpillars chew on leaves. Holes appear in the leaves. Environment: These pests start appearing in the spring, when butterflies begin to reproduce. Treatment: Spray the leaves with an organic anti-caterpillar product, such as pyrethrin, Bacillus thuringiensis, or Bordeaux mixture.

Disease Name: Snails. Symptoms: A path of slime left behind by snails will appear on the leaves. Snails come to eat young leaves. Environment: They appear in wet environments or just after a period of rain. Treatment: To prevent snails from appearing, place wood shavings, ash, or hay around the plant so the snails are unable to climb onto the plants. You can also place a bowl of beer near the plant, a favorite with snails.

Disease Name: Slugs. Symptoms: A path of slime left behind by slugs will appear on the leaves. Slugs come to eat young leaves. Environment: They appear in wet environments or just after a period of rain. Treatment: To prevent slugs from appearing, place wood shavings, ash, or hay around the plant so the slugs are unable to climb onto the plants. You can also place a bowl of beer near the plant, a favorite with slugs.

Disease Name: Aphids. Symptoms: Aphids attack leaves and suck the liquid from them, causing plant growth to slow. Leaves dry out, turn yellow, and fall. The leaves and flowers are deformed. Environment: Aphids can appear starting in spring through the end of fall. Starting in spring, aphids multiply rapidly with the hatching of their eggs. Treatment: They are many techniques to prevent these pests from appearing. Spray nettle, fern, or rhubarb slurry on the leaves. Spray soapy water (made with black soap) onto the leaves. Ladybugs will eat aphid larvae.

Use chamomile tea to control damping-off fungus, which often attacks young seedlings quite suddenly. Just add a spot of tea to the soil around the base of seedlings once a week or use it as a foliage spray.
Follow the sun. Pay attention to how sunlight plays through your yard before choosing a spot for your garden.

To remove the salt deposits that form on clay pots, combine equal parts white vinegar, rubbing alcohol and water in a spray bottle. Apply the mixture to the pot and scrub with a plastic brush. Let the pot dry before you plant anything in it.

Welcome to KhetTech. Your ultimate gardening companion! Our app is designed to help you become a pro in gardening. Whether you\'re a seasoned green thumb or just starting out. With features like plant list, disease detection, journaling, and tips and tricks, we\'ve got you covered every step of the way. Our mission is to empower you with the knowledge and tools you need to grow healthy, thriving plants and enjoy the many rewards of gardening. Join our community of gardening enthusiasts and start growing your dream garden today!

Tip 1: Site Selection and Soil Preparation
Description: Ensure the planting site receives full sunlight and has good drainage for optimal plant growth.
Description: Amend with compost or organic matter to enhance fertility and structure, promoting a healthy root environment.
Description: Planting too deep can suffocate roots, while planting too shallow can expose them to drying out.
Description: After planting, water thoroughly to settle the soil around the roots and eliminate air pockets.
Description: Maintain consistent soil moisture, avoiding water logging and complete drying, especially during the establishment period.
Description: Water your plants deeply but less frequently to encourage deep root growth and improve drought resistance.

Description: Bacterial spot, caused by Xanthomonas spp., affects tomato and pepper plants, leading to small, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit that can become necrotic. Prevention: Use disease-free seeds and transplants, apply copper-based bactericides, and practice good sanitation by removing plant debris and rotating crops.

Description: Definition: Leaf scorch refers to the browning and drying of leaf edges and tips, often due to environmental stressors like drought, high temperatures, or salt accumulation. It can weaken plants and reduce photosynthesis. Prevention: Maintain consistent watering, improve soil health with organic matter, and provide shade during extreme heat. Avoid using high-salt fertilizers.

Description: Definition: Late blight is a severe disease caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans, affecting tomatoes and potatoes. It causes large, dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit, leading to rapid plant decline. Prevention: Use resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, and apply fungicides regularly. Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to prevent spread.

Description: Powdery Mildew Definition: Powdery mildew is a fungal disease affecting a wide variety of plants, characterized by white, powdery spots on leaves and stems. It can cause leaves to yellow, curl, and drop prematurely. Prevention: Ensure good air circulation, avoid overhead watering, and apply sulfur or neem oil-based fungicides. Removing infected plant parts promptly can also help.

Description: Early Blight Definition: Early blight is a common fungal disease in tomatoes and potatoes, caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It results in dark, concentric spots on leaves, stems, and fruit, leading to yellowing and dropping of leaves, which can significantly reduce yield. Prevention: To prevent early blight, practice crop rotation, avoid overhead watering, and ensure good air circulation around plants. Use mulch to prevent soil from splashing onto leaves, and apply copper-based fungicides as needed.
